noun.description: The possibility or likelihood of some future event occurring.
examples: there was no prospect of a reconciliation
training that offered a prospect of continuous employment

noun.description: A person regarded as likely to succeed or as a potential customer, client, etc.
examples: clients deemed likely prospects for active party membership
a viewpoint commanding a magnificent prospect of the estuary

verb.description: Search for mineral deposits in a place, especially by means of experimental drilling and excavation.
examples: the company is also prospecting for gold

origin: Late Middle English (as a noun denoting the action of looking towards a distant object): from Latin prospectus view, from prospicere look forward, from pro- forward + specere to look. Early use, referring to a view of landscape, gave rise to the meaning mental picture (mid 16th century), whence anticipated event.
